pageData.text: In this activity, the factors affecting the rate of an iodine clock reaction will be investigated. In this reaction, two colorless solutions are combined and the reaction is completed when the solution turns a dark blue color. The <button class='glossary-text'>reaction rate</button> will be studied by testing the effects of <button class='glossary-text'>temperature</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>concentration</button>, and addition of a <button class='glossary-text'>catalyst</button> on the rate. The measured data will be used to calculate the <button class='glossary-text'>rate law</button> for the iodine clock reaction.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Ice
Warm water
Pure water*
Timing device or stopwatch

pageData.text: *Bottled or purified water should be used because they lack most of the impurities that are found in tap water. Water that has been filtered through a water purifier (e.g., Brita® or PUR®) works well.

The laboratory experiment may be stopped after the completion of any activity and resumed at a later time. If the experiment is interrupted before it is complete, ensure that all liquids are sealed to prevent evaporation and spillage. Clean the 24-well plate and test tubes and allow them to dry before resuming the next activity.

pageData.text: Enzymes are used to help scientists control the kinetics of chemical reactions. The use of an enzyme will speed up a chemical reaction without being destroyed during the reaction, so it sustains its effect on the reaction kinetics. One of those enzymes is glucose oxidase.

Glucose oxidase is manipulated by bread makers. This enzyme is used to strengthen the dough, as well as increase the volume of the dough. Characterization of the bread shows that the glucose oxidase modifies gluten proteins (gliadins and glutenins) by forming both disulfide and non-disulfide crosslinks. This leads to a more robust dough that can better withstand the rigor of the breadmaking process, such as kneading. However, add too much glucose oxidase and the loaf will begin showing negative characteristics, like stiffness, due to an excessive amount of crosslinking.

pageData.desc: Two hands dusted in flour kneading a large ball of bread dough on a flour-dusted table.
pageData.altText: Two hands dusted in flour kneading a large ball of bread dough on a flour-dusted table.

pageData.text: Chemical kinetics seeks to understand the factors that control . The fundamental concept of chemical kinetics is . According to this theory, reactant molecules must collide with enough force to achieve before a reaction can occur. Activation energy is the minimum amount of energy required to break the chemical bonds of reactant molecules, after which they can form new products. indicates that molecules continuously collide; however, only those collisions that meet or exceed the required activation energy, and those that collide in a favorable orientation, will form new chemical bonds, thus new products. The rate of chemical reactions can be influenced by , reactant , of the reactants, and the presence of a .

pageData.subTitle: Temperature
pageData.text: Kinetic molecular theory defines temperature as a measurement of the average kinetic energy of molecules. The Kelvin temperature scale begins with 0 K, the temperature at which there is no molecular motion. As temperature increases, the average kinetic energy of molecules also increases, which increases their average speed. At higher speeds, molecules collide more frequently and with higher energy, leading to faster reaction rates. Chemical reactions have faster reaction rates at higher temperatures.

pageData.subTitle: Concentration
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Concentration</button> is the quantity of molecules per volume. As an example for liquid solutions, 1 Molar hydrochloric acid (1 M HCl) contains 1 mole of HCl molecules per liter of solution, whereas 2 M HCl contains 2 moles of HCl molecules per liter of solution. The concentration of gas molecules in a closed system is increased by adding more gas per volume, which increases the pressure, or by decreasing the volume of the gas. As molecular concentration of the reactants increases, the frequency of collisions increases, which leads to faster <button class='glossary-text'>reaction rates</button>. Most chemical reactions have faster reaction rates at higher concentrations.

pageData.subTitle: Physical State
pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>physical state</button> of the reactants is important for a reaction to occur. Two solids will have minimal surface area touching one another and hence, very little interaction between the molecules of the two solids. The reaction will usually be very slow. If a solid is added to a solution, a reaction may occur at the surface of the solid. However, if the solid is broken up into smaller pieces, the surface area increases and the rate of reaction will also increase.

Reaction rates are affected by surface area because the greater the surface area, the greater the number of molecular collisions. Molecules must collide with each other for a reaction to occur; therefore, the greater the contact surface area, the greater the probability for molecular collisions. Chemical reactions between molecules in different phases (e.g., gas-solid or liquid-solid) have slow rates because collisions are limited. By contrast, reactions between molecules in a homogeneous solution have a greater probability for molecular interactions and collisions, and have faster reaction rates.

pageData.question: A chemical reaction occurs as a solid is placed in a solution. If the reaction is repeated but the solid is broken up into smaller pieces, what is likely to occur?

options.text: The reaction rate will increase.
The reaction rate will remain the same.
The average kinetic energy of the solution will increase.
The reaction rate will decrease.
The solid will become a catalyst.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: If a solid is added to a solution, a reaction may occur at the surface of the solid. However, if the solid is broken up into smaller pieces, the surface area increases, and the reaction rate will also increase.

pageData.question: Reactions between molecules in a ______ have a greater probability for molecular interactions and collisions and have faster reaction rates.

options.text: homogeneous solution
solid state
gas-solid mixture
liquid-solid mixture
heterogeneous solution

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Reactions between molecules in a homogeneous solution have a greater probability for molecular interactions and collisions and have faster reaction rates.

pageData.subTitle: Catalyst
pageData.text: A <button class='glossary-text'>catalyst</button> is a substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction but is not chemically changed during the reaction. A catalyst provides a mechanism that makes it easier for bonds to break and reform into products. The catalyst lowers the reaction <button class='glossary-text'>activation energy</button> and greatly accelerates the reaction. For example, the decomposition of H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> in an aqueous solution to O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> and H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O is greatly accelerated by the addition of a catalyst. A bottle of 3% hydrogen peroxide will last for years before it completely decomposes to water and oxygen. If a drop of potassium iodide (a catalyst for this reaction) is added to the solution, it will start to react, and within minutes the reaction will be complete. Enzymes are nature’s catalysts and speed up any crucial biochemical reactions in most organisms.

pageData.subTitle: Rate Laws
pageData.text: To properly study the rate of a reaction, a <button class='glossary-text'>rate law</button> must be written. Many reactions occur in multiple steps, and the overall rate of the reaction will depend on the step that takes the longest amount of time. This step is called the <button class='glossary-text'>rate determining step</button>. The rate law for a reaction can only be determined experimentally and provides understanding of the reaction mechanism.

The rate of a chemical reaction, also called <button class='glossary-text'>reaction rate (R)</button> is how long it takes for the reaction to occur. It is defined as the <button class='glossary-text'>concentration</button> change of reactants that occurs during a specified time period. The rate law for a chemical reaction is a mathematical relationship between reaction rate and the concentration of each reactant. Determining the rate law for a chemical reaction can be best explained with the following example and steps:
Step 1: Write the chemical equation:
A + B → Products

Step 2: The is written as being proportional to the starting of each reactant. Brackets ([A] and [B]) represent the starting molar concentrations of each reactant in moles/L or M. However, each reactant may influence the reaction rate differently. Reaction orders are used to indicate the importance of a reactant to the , and are represented by the exponents n and m. If the exponent for reactant A is 1, then the reaction is said to be first-order for A. If the exponent is 2, then the reaction is said to be second-order for A. For most reactions, the exponent is 0, 1, or 2. The exponent value must be determined experimentally because it is the extent to which the concentration of a species affects the rate of a reaction. The reaction order cannot be determined from the chemical equation. The proportional is written using the reaction rate, the concentration of each reactant, and the reaction order for each reactant:
R ∝ [A]n[B]m

Step 3: To write the final rate law, the reaction must be run multiple times. The concentration of each reactant is changed in an orderly approach to determine the impact the rate of that reactant has on the reaction rate. Once the order of reaction for each reactant is determined experimentally, the rate equation is solved by inserting the .
R = k[A]n[B]m
The units for reaction rates are usually expressed as molarity per second (M/s) or the change of concentration over time.

The best method to determine the exponents or the reaction order is to vary the <button class='glossary-text'>concentration</button> of one of the reactants while keeping all other reactant concentrations and reaction conditions constant. For example, examine the following data table for the reaction A + B → Products. In each trial, the starting concentration of one reactant is changed while the other reactant concentration is held constant, and the reaction time is measured and recorded.

The results from Trials 1 and 2 show that the doubles (from 0.04 to 0.08 M/s) as the concentration of A doubles (from 0.10 to 0.20 M). Consider what the exponent n would have to equal for [A] to satisfy this condition.
[A]n = R[2]n = 2
The exponent n would have to equal 1, indicating that the reaction is first-order for A.

Now consider Trials 1 and 3, which show that the reaction rate increases by a factor of four (from 0.04 to 0.16 M/s) as the concentration of B doubles (from 0.10 to 0.20 M). Consider what the exponent m would have to equal for [B] to satisfy this condition.
[B]m = R[2]m = 4
The exponent m would equal 2, indicating that the reaction is second-order for B.
If the answer is not easy to determine by simple inspection of the data, the following equation can be used to determine an unknown exponent:
([A2]/[A2])n = rate2/rate1
Using the values given in the preceding data table, solve the equation for n and m, and confirm that the same values are obtained.
To solve for the exponent (reaction order) of [A],(0.20 M/0.10 M)m = 0.08 M/s/0.04 M/s2n = 2ln 2n = ln 2
n(ln 2) = ln 2n = 1
To solve for the exponent (reaction order) of [B],(0.20 M/0.10 M)m = 0.16 M/s/0.04 M/s2m = 4ln 2m = ln 4m(ln 2) = ln 4m = ln 4ln 2m = 2

When solving for an unknown reaction order, the only reaction variable that can be allowed to change is the <button class='glossary-text'>concentration</button> of the reactant for which the order is being determined. The concentrations of all other reactant species must remain the same. Furthermore, the reaction <button class='glossary-text'>temperature</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>physical state</button> of the reactants must be held constant for all trials.
The rate-law expression can be written once the numerical values of the reaction order exponents (n and m) are known.
R = k[A]n[B]m
R = k[A]1[B]2

In our example, the reaction order with respect to [A] is 1, and the reaction order with respect to [B] is 2. The overall order of the reaction is the sum of the order for each reactant, which in this example is 1 + 2 = 3.

Once the reaction orders have been experimentally determined, the rate constant k can be determined by using data from any of the trials. For example, using the data from Trials 1 and 3 give the same rate constant.

pageData.subTitle: Trial 1
pageData.text: R = k[A][B]2k = R / [A][B]2k = (0.04 M/s) / [0.10 M][0.10 M]2k = (0.040 M/s) / [0.10 M][0.01 M2]k = (0.040 M/s) / [0.001 M3]k = 40 M-2 s-1

pageData.subTitle: Trial 3
pageData.text: R = k[A][B]2k = R / [A][B]2k = (0.160 M/s) / [0.10 M][0.20 M]2k = (0.160 M/s) / [0.10 M][0.04 M2]k = (0.160 M/s) / [0.004 M3]k = 40 M-2 s-1

pageData.subTitle: Iodine Clock Reaction
pageData.text: The iodine clock reaction performed in this laboratory investigation occurs in the following three steps:
Step 1:3I– (aq) + H2O2 (aq) + 2H+ (aq) → I3– (aq) + 2H2O (l)
Step 2:I3– (aq) + 2S2O32– (aq) → 3I– (aq) + S4 O62– (aq)
Step 3:2I3– (aq) + starch → starch - I5– complex + l– (aq)

In reaction step 1, iodide ions are oxidized by hydrogen peroxide ions in an acidic solution to form triiodide ions. In step 2, the triiodide ions are reduced by thiosulfate (S2O32–) to form iodide ions. This reaction occurs quickly, and triiodide ions are consumed by thiosulfate as quickly as they are formed. Reaction 3 only occurs when all thiosulfate is consumed. After all the thiosulfate is consumed, triiodide ions are now available to react with starch to form a pentaiodide—starch complex that is a dark blue. The appearance of a dark blue-black color signals the end of the three reactions. The reaction begins when the reactants are mixed together, and ends when the dark blue-black color is observed.

pageData.question: Which of the following is the fastest step in an iodine clock reaction?

options.text: the consumption of triiodide ions (I<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub><sup class='bodySupscript'>-</sup>) by thiosulfate (S<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub><sup class='bodySupscript'>2-</sup>)
the oxidation of iodide ions (I<sup class='bodySupscript'>-</sup>) by hydrogen peroxide (H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>)
the reaction of triiodide ions (I<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub><sup class='bodySupscript'>-</sup>) with starch
the formation of pentaiodide-starch complexes
the reduction of hydrogen peroxide (H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>) by iodide ions (I<sup class='bodySupscript'>-</sup>)

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Step 2 of the iodide clock reaction, in which triiodide ions are consumed by thiosulfate, is the fastest of the three reaction steps.

pageData.question: How will you know when the iodide clock reaction is over?

options.text: a dark blue-black color is observed
an orange color is observed
a yellow color is observed
a red color is observed
a pink-purple color is observed

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The reaction begins when the reactants are mixed and ends when a dark blue-black color is observed.

Step 3 only occurs when all thiosulfate is consumed. After all the thiosulfate is consumed, triiodide ions are now available to react with starch to form a pentaiodide—starch complex that is a dark blue. pageData.desc: This map describes the procedural workflow for Activities 1 and 2. In Activity 1, you start by performing an iodine clock reaction. If the reaction time is between 18 and 22 seconds, proceed to the last step in this activity. If the reaction time is greater than 22 seconds, repeat the iodine clock reaction with decreased sodium thiosulfate. If the reaction time is less than 22 seconds, repeat the iodine clock reaction with increased sodium thiosulfate. Finally, you will record the number of drops of sodium thiosulfate for the ideal reaction time. In Activity 2, you will perform a three different series of iodine clock reactions, each with varying concentrations of KI, H2O2 and HCl. Then, you will calculate the average reaction time at each KI concentration. Finally, you will calculate the reaction rate at each KI concentration.calculate the reaction rate at each KI concentration.
pageData.altText: This map describes the procedural workflow for Activities 1 and 2. In Activity 1, you start by performing an iodine clock reaction. If the reaction time is between 18 and 22 seconds, proceed to the last step in this activity. If the reaction time is greater than 22 seconds, repeat the iodine clock reaction with decreased sodium thiosulfate. If the reaction time is less than 22 seconds, repeat the iodine clock reaction with increased sodium thiosulfate. Finally, you will record the number of drops of sodium thiosulfate for the ideal reaction time. In Activity 2, you will perform a three different series of iodine clock reactions, each with varying concentrations of KI, H2O2 and HCl. Then, you will calculate the average reaction time at each KI concentration. Finally, you will calculate the reaction rate at each KI concentration.calculate the reaction rate at each KI concentration.

pageData.desc:
This map describes the procedural workflow for Activities 3 through 5. In Activity 3, you will need to prepare water baths at three different temperatures. Then, perform an iodine clock reaction in each water bath. Finally, you will record the reaction time at each temperature.

In Activity 4, you will need to create a dilute copper(II) sulfate catalyst solution. Then, perform a series of iodine clock reactions with varying quantities of catalyst. Finally, record the reaction time of each trial.
In Activity 5, you will need to calculate the average reaction rate at each reactant concentration. Then, calculate the average reaction order for each reactant. Next, you will need to record the rate law expression. Finally, you will determine the overall order of the reaction.
pageData.altText:
This map describes the procedural workflow for Activities 3 through 5. In Activity 3, you will need to prepare water baths at three different temperatures. Then, perform an iodine clock reaction in each water bath. Finally, you will record the reaction time at each temperature.

In Activity 4, you will need to create a dilute copper(II) sulfate catalyst solution. Then, perform a series of iodine clock reactions with varying quantities of catalyst. Finally, record the reaction time of each trial.
In Activity 5, you will need to calculate the average reaction rate at each reactant concentration. Then, calculate the average reaction order for each reactant. Next, you will need to record the rate law expression. Finally, you will determine the overall order of the reaction.

pageData.subTitle: Personal protective equipment (PPE)
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Read all instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).
Copper sulfate is harmful if swallowed. Hydrogen peroxide can cause serious eye damage. Potassium iodide may cause an allergic skin reaction. Hydrochloric acid causes skin and eye irritation.
Hydrogen peroxide causes skin irritation.
Copper sulfate is very toxic to aquatic life.
Hydrochloric acid can be toxic if inhaled.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of these is LEAST likely to influence the rate of chemical reactions?

options.text: presence of oxygen
physical state of the reactants
temperature
reactant concentration
presence of a catalyst

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes temperature according to kinetic molecular theory?

options.text: A measure of the average kinetic energy of molecules.
A measure of the average potential energy of molecules.
A measure of the quantity of molecules per volume.
A measure of the probability of molecular collision.
A measure of the average surface area between two reactants.

assestmentData.question: According to kinetic molecular theory, under what circumstances will a collision between two molecules result in the formation of new chemical bonds?

options.text: The collision meets the required activation energy in a favorable orientation.
The collision is less than the required activation energy.
The collision takes place multiple times, each with a different orientation.
The collision occurs at a favorable temperature and pH.
The collision meets or exceeds the angle of orientation at a specific temperature.

assestmentData.question: A substance is considered a catalyst in a chemical reaction when it increases the rate of the reaction under what circumstances?

options.text: The substance is not chemically changed by the reaction.
The substance changes state as a result of the reaction.
The substance becomes a product of the reaction.
The substance changes the activation energy for future reactions.
The substance increases the temperature of the reactants.

assestmentData.question: The overall rate of a chemical reaction depends on which of the following steps?

options.text: the slowest step
the fastest step
the second-to-last step
the first step
the step requiring a catalyst

assestmentData.question: The units for reaction rates are usually expressed as ___.

options.text: molarity/second (M/s)
percentages (%)
moles • Kelvin (mol•K)
degrees Celsius (°C)
collisions/second (C/s)

assestmentData.question: What is the best method for determining the reaction order for reactant A in the chemical reaction A + B --> Products?

options.text: Change the concentrations of A, keep B constant, and compare the reaction rates.
Change the temperatures of B, keep A constant, and compare the reaction times.
Add a catalyst in one reaction and compare reaction time to reaction without catalyst.
Divide the concentration of A by the concentration of B, then times by reaction time.
Change the order in which the reactants are combined and compare the reaction rates.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following signals the end of an iodine clock reaction?

options.text: dark blue-black color change
crystal precipitate formation
pH indicator color change to colorless
30 seconds have elapsed
reaction volume decreases by half

assestmentData.question: The 0.1 M hydrochloric acid provided in your lab kit for this investigation is a strong acid. Which of the following safety hazards is associated with this chemical?

options.text: It is a skin and eye irritant; it can be toxic if inhaled.
It is a respiratory tract irritant; it is very harmful to aquatic life.
It is a mutagen; it will stain skin and clothing.
It may cause an allergic skin reaction; it is highly flammable.
It may cause harm to an unborn child; it is a potential choking hazard.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the activity that must be completed to ensure the accurate completion of all subsequent activities in this investigation?

options.text: determine the amount of sodium thiosulfate to use in each reaction
determine the concentration of the provided hydrogen peroxide
determine the reaction time of an iodine clock reaction under standard conditions
determine the catalyst of an iodine clock reaction
determine the rate law of an iodine clock reaction

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the Activity sections to familiarize yourself with all steps before you begin the experiment.
Obtain all required materials.
Fill a plastic medicine cup with pure water.

In this investigation, use a different well in the well plate for each reaction. Do not cross-contaminate the contents of one well to another, and do not allow microdroplets of the solutions to splash into multiple wells during delivery. Use a different row of the plate for each activity. Start at the left well and proceed right. Solutions can be discarded after each activity. Before reusing the plate, rinse all wells several times with purified water and allow them to dry thoroughly.

In Activity 1, you will perform calibration tests to determine the number of drops of sodium thiosulfate (Na<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>S<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub>) solution that should be used in all subsequent experiments in this investigation. You will repeat some of the steps of this activity in subsequent activities to perform trials of the iodine clock reaction.
Orient the 24-well plate so that there are four wells across (horizontal axis) and six wells down (vertical axis).
In the top-left well, place 8 drops of KI.
Add 2 drops of HCl to the KI solution in the well.
Add 4 drops of starch to the KI solution in the well.
Add 8 drops of Na<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>S<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub> solution (sodium thiosulfate) to the KI solution in the well.
Mix the solution by gently swirling the 24-well plate in a small circle on the table.
With the syringe, draw up 0.4 mL of H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>.
As the H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> is added to the solution in the well, begin timing.
Add the hydrogen peroxide quickly but without splashing.
Mix the solution by gentle swirling, and monitor the color.
Record the amount of time it takes for the entire solution to turn a dark blue or black color in Data Table 1.
If the solution took 18–22 seconds to turn dark blue, then no additional calibration trials are necessary.

If the reaction took more than 18–22 seconds, then the amount of sodium thiosulfate must be decreased. Repeat steps 1–10 in the next well in the row, but add 7 drops of Na<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>S<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub> instead of 8 drops. Continue the trials, reducing the Na<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>S<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub> by 1 drop for each trial, until it takes between 18–22 seconds for the dark blue color to appear.

If the reaction took less than 18–22 seconds, then the amount of sodium thiosulfate must be increased. Repeat steps 1–10 in the next well in the row, but add 9 drops of Na<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>S<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub> instead of 8 drops. Continue the trials, adding 1 more drop of Na<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>S<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub> for each trial, until it takes between 18–22 seconds for the dark blue color to appear.
Record the number of drops of Na2S2O3 used to achieve the approximately 20-second change in Data Table 1. This is the number of drops that will be used in all subsequent experiments.

In Activity 2, you will perform three different sets of iodine clock reaction trials, each set focusing on the effects of changing the of a different substance - potassium iodide (KI), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), or hydrochloric acid (HCl). For each set of trials, you will record the reaction times of each trial, calculate the average reaction time for similar trials, and calculate the rate for similar trials.

typeBefore.title: Concentration of KI (3 steps)
typeBefore.text: Perform steps 1-10 described in the calibration activity, but use the number of drops of each reactant that are specified in Table 1. Use the number of drops of Na<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>S<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub> determined in Activity 1 for all trials. In this set of trials, only the amounts of KI and water are changed. The water is added to ensure that the final volume and the <button class='glossary-text'>concentrations</button> of all reactants are constant.

pageData.text: Record the reaction times for these trials in Data Table 2a.
Calculate the average reaction time for similar trials (i.e., trials 1 and 2).
Calculate the rate for similar trials, 1/Time.

typeBefore.title: H2O2 Concentration Effects (3 steps)
typeBefore.text: These trials will follow the same procedure as specified above, but this set of trials will vary the concentration of H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> (see Table 2). As stated above, the amount of water added to each reaction must be adjusted so that the final volume and the concentrations of all reactants are constant. To avoid contamination, it may be best to rinse out the syringe and add the required amount of water to all wells before starting any trials.

pageData.text: Record the reaction times for these trials in Data Table 2b.
Calculate the average reaction time for similar trials (i.e., trials 1 and 2).
Calculate the rate for similar trials, 1/Time.

typeBefore.title: Concentration of HCl (9 steps)

pageData.text: This trial follows the same procedure as specified for determining the concentration of KI (see Table 3), but it varies the concentration of HCl.

To vary the HCl concentration, a series of new HCl concentrations will be prepared from the stock 0.1 M HCl reagent (the 0.1 M HCl stock reagent is the 100% HCl solution). The same volume of HCl will be used in each trial (2 drops), but the HCl concentration contained in this volume will change.
In the first well of a row, add 15 drops of 0.1 M HCl and 5 drops of pure water. Swirl to mix. This is the 75% HCl solution.
In the second well of the row, add 10 drops of HCl and 10 drops of pure water. Swirl to mix. This is the 50% HCl solution.
In the third well of the row, add 5 drops of HCl and 15 drops of pure water. Swirl to mix. This is the 25% HCl solution.
Record the reaction times in Data Table 2c.
Calculate the average reaction time for similar trials (i.e., trials 1 and 2).
Calculate the rate for similar trials, 1/Time.
Rinse well plate three times with bottled water. Then clean using soap and water and finally rinse again three times with bottled water. Let air dry or blot dry using clean paper towels.

In Activity 3, you will perform an iodine clock reaction at three different <button class='glossary-text'>temperatures</button> (room temperature, hot and cold) using water baths. You will record the reaction time at each temperature.

Place one test tube into each of the three plastic cups and allow the tube to lean against the edge. Mark the cups with a horizontal line at the halfway points of the test tubes, and remove the test tubes from the cups.
Prepare three water baths as follows:

text: For a room-temperature water bath, add room-temperature water to one cup until the water reaches the mark. Room is approximately 25 °C. If the water temperature varies greatly from this temperature, add a small amount of warm or cool water until it reaches this temperature. Record the temperature in Data Table 3.

For a cold-water bath, add ice to a cup until the ice is approximately halfway to the mark and then add water until the level reaches the mark. The cold-water bath should be approximately 5 °C, or approximately 20 °C below that of the room-temperature bath. Immediately before using the cold-water bath, record its temperature in Data Table 3.

For a hot-water bath, add hot tap water to a cup until the water level reaches the mark. Ensure that the temperature of this water is approximately 45 °C, or approximately 20 °C above that of the room-temperature bath. Immediately before using the hot-water bath, record its temperature in Data Table 3.

pageData.text: In this activity, the KI, HCl, starch, and Na<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>S<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>3</sub> solutions will be added to one test tube and placed in the appropriate water bath for 5 minutes. The amounts of each reactant are the same as those used in the first trial in Activity 2 (<button class='resource-text'>Table 1</button>).

Add 0.4 mL H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> to a clean test tube, and place this tube in the appropriate water bath for 5 minutes. This serves to pre-equilibrate the H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> solution to the required temperature before adding it to the reaction.
After preparing the reaction solutions (step 3 of this activity), gently swirl the solution so the reactants are mixed and the solution reaches the temperature of its water bath.

When the reactants have reached the temperature of the water bath, add the pre-equilibrated H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> to the reaction test tube and begin timing. The reaction test tube should be kept in the water bath.
Swirl the solution and monitor the color.
Record the amount of time it takes for the room-temperature reactants to turn blue-black in Data Table 3.
Repeat the mixing and reaction processes with the pairs of tubes in both the hot-water and cold-water baths. Record the time it takes for the reactions to reach a blue-black color in Data Table 3.

In Activity 4, you will perform a series of iodine clock reaction trials, each with a different quantity of dilute copper(II) sulfate solution as the <button class='glossary-text'>catalyst</button>. You will record the reaction time for each trial.
Add one drop of 0.5 M copper(II) sulfate solution to one of the wells.
Add about 3 mL of pure water to the well to dilute the copper sulfate. Swirl the solution to mix.
Repeat the reaction with the reactant quantities in Table 4. Use the dilute copper sulfate solution that was just prepared.
Record the time in Data Table 4.

In Activity 5, you will use the data from Activity 2 to perform a series of calculations to determine the <button class='glossary-text'>rate law</button> expression and the overall order of the reaction.

The is determined by observing the effect of different of I-, H2O2, and HCl on the rate of the reaction (Activity 2). The exponents (reaction order) of each reactant are determined by evaluating the change in when only that reactant concentration is changed. The overall chemical reaction is written as follows:3I- (aq) + H2O2 (aq) + 2H+ (aq) → I3- (aq) + 2HO2 (l)
The rate law in terms of the reactants is given by(R = k [I-] m [H2O2] n [H+] p )
For each reactant, determine the order with respect to that reactant using the following formula: concentration 1 concentration 2 X = rate 1 rate 2
In the equation, x represents the corresponding exponent in the rate law (i.e., n, m, or p). Refer to the background for specifics on this calculation. Record the results Data Table 5.
For each reactant, perform the calculation 3 times from highest concentration to lowest concentration, i.e., compare 1 and 2, 2 and 3, and 3 and 4.
Determine the average reaction order for each reactant and record them in Data Table 5.
Round the average to the nearest whole integer (i.e., 0, 1, 2, 3…) and record these as the final values for m, n, and p.

Take the rate law expression for this reaction, R = k [I–] m [H2O2] n [H+] p, and insert the exponents for m, n, and p that you determined in the preceding steps. If any of the experimentally determined exponents is 0 (i.e., no change in rate after doubling in concentration), then mathematically the value will be 1 and the exponent will fall out of the rate equation. Record the rate law expression in Data Table 5.
Determine the overall order of this reaction by finding the sum of all the exponents. Record this in Data Table 5.

text: Dispose of reaction solutions in the sink, and then rinse the sink well.
Clean and dry all equipment and return it to the equipment kit.
Clean the work space.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

text: How many drops will be used in the remaining experiments?

pageData.title: Data Table 2a. Effects of KI Concentration
Data Table 2b. Effects of H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> Concentration
Data Table 2c. Effects of H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup> Concentration

text: Explain how each of these treatments affected the reaction rate. Describe the effect at a molecular level.
How did the addition of copper(II) sulfate affect the reaction rate? Did the amount of catalyst affect the reaction rate?

pageData.title: Data Table 5. Orders of Reactants in the Rate Law
pageData.text: R = k[I-]m[H2O2]n[H+]p   e.g. ( concentration 1 concentration 2 )X = rate 1 rate 2

text: Use the rate-law expression you determined for Data Table 5 to answer the following questions.
nestedOrderList: If the concentration of I<sup class='bodySupscript'>-</sup> was doubled, how would that affect the reaction rate?
If the concentration of H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> was halved, how would that affect the reaction rate?
If the concentrations of I<sup class='bodySupscript'>-</sup> and H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> were doubled, how would that affect the reaction rate?
If the concentration of H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup> (HCl) was doubled, how would that affect the reaction rate?

pageData.altText: This map describes the procedural workflow for Activities 1 and 2. In Activity 1, you start by performing an iodine clock reaction. If the reaction time is between 18 and 22 seconds, proceed to the last step in this activity. If the reaction time is greater than 22 seconds, repeat the iodine clock reaction with decreased sodium thiosulfate. If the reaction time is less than 22 seconds, repeat the iodine clock reaction with increased sodium thiosulfate. Finally, you will record the number of drops of sodium thiosulfate for the ideal reaction time. In Activity 2, you will perform a three different series of iodine clock reactions, each with varying concentrations of KI, H2O2 and HCl. Then, you will calculate the average reaction time at each KI concentration. Finally, you will calculate the reaction rate at each KI concentration.calculate the reaction rate at each KI concentration.

This map describes the procedural workflow for Activities 3 through 5. In Activity 3, you will need to prepare water baths at three different temperatures. Then, perform an iodine clock reaction in each water bath. Finally, you will record the reaction time at each temperature.

In Activity 4, you will need to create a dilute copper(II) sulfate catalyst solution. Then, perform a series of iodine clock reactions with varying quantities of catalyst. Finally, record the reaction time of each trial.
In Activity 5, you will need to calculate the average reaction rate at each reactant concentration. Then, calculate the average reaction order for each reactant. Next, you will need to record the rate law expression. Finally, you will determine the overall order of the reaction.

data.title: Activation energy
data.content: The minimum amount of energy required to break the chemical bonds of reactant molecules, after which they can form new products

data.title: Catalyst
data.content: A substance that can speed up chemical reactions by lowering the activation energy required for the reaction

data.title: Collision theory
data.content: According to this theory, reactant molecules must collide with enough force to achieve activation energy before a reaction can occur

data.title: Concentration
data.content: The quantity of molecules per volume

data.title: Kinetic molecular theory
data.content: Molecules continuously collide; however, only those collisions that meet or exceed the required activation energy, and those that collide in a favorable orientation, will form new chemical bonds, thus new products

data.title: Physical state
data.content: Characterizes the form of a substance, generally gas, liquid, or solid, at a given temperature and pressure

data.title: Rate determining step
data.content: The overall rate of the reaction will depend on the step that takes the longest amount of time.

data.title: Rate law
data.content: A mathematical relationship between reaction rate and the concentration of each reactant

data.title: Reaction rate (R)
data.content: How long it takes for the reaction to occur

data.title: Reaction rate constant (k)
data.content: The relationship between the impact the rate of that reactant has on the chemical reaction

data.title: Temperature
data.content: A measurement of the average speed of the molecules of gas and is expressed in units of Kelvin (K)
